title: Pyung Kim
text:
I am a Ph.D. candidate in Public Policy and Political Economy at the University of Texas at Dallas, where I was admitted with the highest honors. My research centers on the intersection of geography, public policy, and environmental health, examining the causes and consequences of geographic disparities in health and socioeconomic status. I utilize GIS and machine learning techniques to identify areas in need of targeted, localized policy interventions. I also apply design-based econometrics to evaluate the causal impacts of public policy.

Before joining UT Dallas, I served as a research assistant at the Korea Institute of Public Administration, a national think tank operating under the Prime Minister. I earned my B.A. in Public Administration from Ajou University, graduating with summa cum laude. Subsequently, I obtained my MPA at Yonsei University in South Korea. Throughout my academic journey, I have been fortunate to receive several prestigious scholarships based on merit from the Korea Ministry of Education, the National Research Foundation of Korea, the Korean Association for Policy Studies, Ajou University, Yonsei University, and UT Dallas.





Research Interests

Environment and Health, and Disability
Geographic Disparities and Social Mobility
GIS and Spatial Analysis
Applied Machine Learning
Causal Inference and Policy Evaluation

title: Pyung Kim
text:
I am a Ph.D. candidate in Public Policy and Political Economy at the University of Texas at Dallas, where I was admitted with the highest honors. My research focuses on spatial epidemiology and policy evaluation. Using GIS and machine learning, I identify areas requiring policy interventions, while employing statistics and econometrics to assess the causal impacts of the policies. Deep learning approaches are also a part of my toolkit, enabling me to forecast demand for public services and devise personalized policy interventions. My ultimate research goal is to reduce health disparities and advocate for inclusive institutions.

Before joining UT Dallas, I served as a research assistant at the Korea Institute of Public Administration, a national think tank operating under the Prime Minister. I earned my B.A. in Public Administration from Ajou University, graduating with summa cum laude. Subsequently, I obtained my MPA at Yonsei University in South Korea. Throughout my academic journey, I have been fortunate to receive several prestigious scholarships based on merit from the Korea Ministry of Education, the National Research Foundation of Korea, the Korean Association for Policy Studies, Ajou University, Yonsei University, and UT Dallas.

text:
Junior Scholar Intensive Training (JSIT) Summer Workshop at the University of Wisconsin-Madison



In the summer of 2024, I participated in a week-long workshop at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, which provided emerging scholars with training and mentorship to develop research ideas and draft an initial research proposal relevant to the Social Security Administration (SSA), its programs, policies, and beneficiaries.
The workshop is supported by the SSA’s Retirement and Disability Research Consortium.
